rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The oxidation of organic compounds.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Since an alkaline solution of iodine was first used by Lieben (l) as an oxidizing agent the reaction has been called the Lieben reaction. It is extremely sensitive in some cases, but it is by no means specific for any one substance. Generally, all those organic compounds containing the grouping R-C combined to oxygen will react either with or without the formation of iodoform. In the course of experiments dealing with the action of hydrogen peroxide on organic substances it was found necessary to employ iodometric methods of estimation whereever possible. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The biology of the tarnished plant bug (Lygus Pratensis L.).
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This thesis comprises the results of a study covering a period of three years on the bionomics of the tarnished plant bug, Lygus pratensis Linnaeus. A review of the existing literature, which is voluminous, dealing with this inseot, has shown that although a great deal has been acoomplished in working out the various phases of life history and control, individual studies have been for the most part fragmentary and in many instances incorrect. Many points of importance have been overlooked or merely touched upon and much time has been invested in control work which has been oarried out before adequate knowledge of the b1ological phases of the problem has been obtained. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Entomology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Constitution of the so-called tetrabromobutyraldehyde ; An investigation into the 'super-molecular' structure of polyethyleneoxide and divinylether
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The melting points of symmetrical tetrabromoethylether, of Freundlers Compound, and of a mixture of equal parts of the two were found to be identical. The analyses were also in agreement, thus definitely establishing the identification of Freundler's Compound as symmetrical tetrabroraoethylether. It seems probable that both 'this and tetrabromobutyraldehyde are present in the reaction mixture obtained in the bromination of paracetaldehyde, but that the latter has not, as yet, been isolated. The preparation of divinyl ether from BB* dichloroethylether constitutes a new synthesis of this product and makes it readily available for investigation. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Cellulose Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The political and constitutional implications of the1926 Imperial Conference.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The Imperial Conferenoe of 1926 was one of the outstanding events in world politios since the war. It might equally well be said that it was one of the most misunderstood. Many claimed that it destroyed the British Empire and established a new status for Great Britain and the Dominions - a status of full international independenoe, in which the only unity was the crown. This alleged result was alarming to all who believed in the empire, and a source of pride to all who harbored desires for its destruction. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The psychology of behaviourism : with special reference to the behaviouristic attitude in abnormal psychology.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The life history of any science is filled with tribulations and hardships of various descriptions. Time and time again, when a science seemed to have reached a satisfactory stage of development, events have ooourred which have caused a disruption in the science, and consequently necessitated a complete renewal of the fundamental assumptions of that science. Psychology, like the other fields of knowledge, has by no means found its progress an easy one. Beginning as a study of the soul and the mind, it gradually became the study of consciousness and finally of behaviour.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Psychology, Pathological.
Psychology.
Behaviorism (Psychology)

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The striated discharge in gases.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Many theories of the cause of striations in gases have been put forth by various authors (1). The early theories entirely neglected any effect which the walls of the tube had on the discharge. In the more recent attempts (2) at explaining the distribution of potential and the striated positive column, the experimental results of Brose (3) are generally accepted and used as a basis for comparing theory with experiment. Brose found the distribution of potential in the Crookes' dark space from the observation of the Stark effect on certain lines. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A critical study of the teaching of English in the Protestant schools of Montreal and the surrounding district.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Tradition is no longer a safe stronghold. We are living in an age of "whys" and "whereforestf and current educational practice is not without its critics. Many people who do notsubscribe to the theory, held by some historians, that each and every century can be distinguished by an appellation characteristic of the time, would concur, nevertheless, in calling the present era "The Century of Science." Our age is primarily a scientific one which has expressed itself in the swift introduction into schools of manual training, vocational, and commercial courses. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Psychology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: On the influence of structure upon the ability of organic compounds to polymerize.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The following is an account of an investigation into the phenomena of polymerisation. The study of the hydrocarbons, particularly isoprene, butadiene and the styrene hydrocarbons has been vigorously pursued for the last twenty years owing to the importance of rubber and rubber-like compounds in industry. A number of such studies have been made in this laboratory under the direction of Dr. G. S. Whitby. On the other hand, although there is a wealth of observations on other types of polymerisable compounds, there has been little done with regard to a comparative study. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Adsorption of ions at a water surface.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Quincke (1) was the first to make observations on the electrification of liquid-gas interfaces. He found that the passage of an electric current through a capillary tube containing water caused a movement of the water surface, which was exactly proportional to the quantity of electricity passed. He also noted that the passage of a current through a liquid containing gas bubbles caused the latter to move towards an electrode. In his experiments the motion of these air bubbles was investigated in narrow glass capillary tubes, and the bubbles were found to move towards the anode when submerged, but towards the cathode when the water was replaced by turpentine. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The Negro in Canada.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Canada was settled by two large slave-owning nations during the per1od that Negro slavery flourished, but few slaves were brought here. As an adjacent territory offering freedom itwas for nearly a hundred years the refuge of slaves escap1ng from the United States, yet Negroes have always been a very small part of its population. The twelve m1llion Negroes in the United States and the seven million in the West Indies are much nearer than the European countries which have poured millions of immigrants into Canada, but their contribution has been negligible. Is 1t mere chance that they have not come 1n larger numbers? Does the lack of economic attract1on expla1n their absence? Is it the coldness of the climate that has prevented extensive Negro settlement? Or has there been some direct or indirect influence in Canadian public pol1cy? It is the purpose of this thesis to attempt an answer to these quest1ons by exam1n1ng the historical background of the Negro in Canada, and the status and opportunities of the race under the conditions of life 1n this country. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.
Blacks -- Canada.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Further investigations of the distribution of stress in welded joints.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: One of the outstanding developments in the structural industry in recent years has been the rapid growth of welding as a means of building up and connecting structural members.However, despite the many successfully welded structures that have been built in the last few months, engineers still seem to lack confidence in welding. One of the principal reasons for this is the dearth of knowledge ot the physical characterist1cs of welded connections. This ignorance also necessitates the use of large uneconomical safety factors in their design. Many problems on the properties of welded joints are awaiting solution. Research with a view to solving these will do much to create confidence in welding and will lay a firm foundation upon which working stresses can be based. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Engineering.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Les origines du journalisme canadien-français.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Comme notre sujet traite des origines du journalisme canadien-français,nous avons été obligés de nous aider des commencements de la colonie de la Nouvelle France, afin de pouvoir révéler son évolution par les différentes étapes qu'il traversa avant de prendre la forme du journal après la conquête de 1760. Pour nous,le journalisme canadien-français est marqué par l'esprit de cinq époques dans lesquelles l'histoire du Canada est divisée. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Journalism -- Québec (Province) -- History.
French.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Investigations on invertebrate blood.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The matter of this thesis falls under two heads, first, an inquiry into some of the factors influencing the uptake of oxygen by the respiratory pigment haemocyanin, and second, an elucidation of an enzyme system in the blood of decapod Crustacea. It will be more convenient to discuss these two subjects separately, although experiments on the first led directly to the investigation of the second. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Invertebrates.
Blood.
Zoology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: American and British influences on Canadian news content : as shown by a study of two Montreal newspapers.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: No one with real news to tell ever lacked an audience. After food, clothing and shelter, the tidings of the world has ranked with most of us as a prime necessity. A courierservice was among the first organizations of primitive man. It was probably as interesting and important for the primitive trader to know where he could trade a goat-skin for a spear, and learn about Tiglath-Pileser's latest conquest, as it is for us to mow where we can exchange our money for merchandise or learn the results of the Naval Parley. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Sociology.
Reporters and reporting -- Québec (Province) -- Montréal.
Montreal star.
Gazette (Montréal, Québec)

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Bank credit in Canada.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It is estimated that at least ninety percent of the business of Canada and the United States is carried on by means of credit and credit instruments. For this reason credit is sometimes described as the life-blood sustaining the business body. Decrease its flow through one member and it languishes, divert it and it dies. A good system of creating anddistributing this credit is, therefore, of prime importance in the economic development of the country. The ultimate object of this thesis is to ascertain whether the present Canadian banking system is meeting in a satisfactory manner, the credit needs of the country. This will involve the study of two distinct questions - firstly, the creation and general control of credit, and secondly, the distribution of this credit among the various interests in the country. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Le catholicisme de M. Paul Bouget : etudié dans ses principaux romans et nouvelles.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Monsieur Paul Bourget est un des écrivains le plus en vogue et dont l'influenee morale et religieuse, se fait sentir dans toutes 1es classes de la societé. Il est reconnu partout le monde comme un maitre puissant en littérature. Bien peu de critiques nieront qu'i1 ne soit artiste; mais qu'il soit un maitre de spiritualite, que son oeuvre soit morale et que son catholicisme soit de bon aloi n'est pas accepté de tous les critiques; i1 y a difference d'opinion meme parmi les critiques catho1iques sur cette question. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bourget, Paul, 1852-1935 -- Religion.
Bourget, Paul, 1852-1935 -- Criticism and interpretation.
French.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Capital and financial organization in Canada.
rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Economics and Political Science
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The financial picture of a hundred years ago would be merely a pencil sketch when compared to the elaborate picture which would depict the business structure of the present day. Although in the picture, each bold stroke of colour becomes lost in the general outline, each one is in itself an essential part. so it is with the structure of industry, commerce and finance to-day. Mr. Woodrow Wilson said, "We have witnessed in modern business the submergence of the individual within the organization and yet the inorease to extraordinarydegree of the power of the individual - of the individual who happens to control the organization. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.
Capital -- Canada.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Calorimetric measurements in relation to surface phenomena.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The purpose of the work described in this paper was two fold. First, to determine the heats of solutions of potassium chloride in water and the specific heats of po1tassium chloride solutions; and, secondly, to determine the surface energy of solid potassium chloride. The latter is more unusual and so perhaps of greater interest. The surface energy of any two phase system has its seat at the boundary of the two phases and this energy varies with the exte:i.1sion and character of the interface. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Kinetics of chemical change in gaseous systems : the decomposition of diethyl ether on the surface of platinum.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The mechanism at a chemical reaction is determined by a study of the rate of reaction. In the investigation of reaction velocities, gaseous systems offer the greatest advantage; at for although one cannot follow any given raolecule the kinetic theory gives an insight as to what the average molecule is doing. Only a few reactions are known which take place in the gaseous phase, tite majority of such reactions take place on the walls of the containing vessel. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Provincial public finance in Canada.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This monograph has been written in an attempt to supply a long felt need, a brief yet comprehensive survey of the fiscal basis of Canadian federalism. It aims to supply the facts underlying the present important and pressing problems of provincial finance by denoting the historical background and constitutional restrictions bearing on the subject, the difficulties and inadequacies of the present situation, and proposed lines of reform. The subject wss suggested by a perusal of Dr. Solomon Vineberg's thesis on "Provincial and Local Taxation in Canada", which, written in 1912, before the significant changes caused by the war had been effected, is out-dated as a source for understanding the situation of to-day. His subject has been broadened out into finance rather than the narrower field of taxation, and municipal finance has been relegated to the background. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The Cynewulf question.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The study of Old English poetry reveals the important part that the Church played in its development. Towards the close of the 6th century, the conversion of the English to Christianity was begun by Roman missionaries. A century later it was the dominant religion in all the English kingdoms. Although the youngest of the Christian churches, the English Church had the most religious zeal, in addition to warmth and depth of religious sentiment. This was shown in the pilgrimages, the works of Christian Charity, and in the rich gifts to the Church. Kings and queens are known to have erected convents and monasteries, and after renouncing their crowns, to have given themselves, up to prayer and meditation. The missionaries also, did great work among the sti11 pagan tribes on the continent. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Cynewulf.
English.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The federal income tax in Canada.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Although it was not until 1917 that a federal income tax was first imposed in Canada, the Dominion Parliament had the constitutional right to do so from its very inception at Confederation. No enabling amendment to the constitution ot Canada - such as was necessary to that of the United States of America - was required; for, pursuant to the provisions of the British North America Act,l867, the jurisdiction of the Federal Parliament extends to "the raising of money by any mode or system of taxation". Money raised by an income tax is unquestionably money raised by a "mode or system of taxation". [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.
Income tax -- Canada.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The question of marriage in the novels of 1880-1900.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In the early years or Queen Victoria's reign, theologians and educators, supported by an overwhelming majority of the public, upheld the sacrament of marriage and all that it implied. In this twentieth century the point of view has changed considerably, and many go so far as to consider the marriage ceremony important only as a legal formality. It can be said that a great body of public opinion no longer considers the marris.ge tie unbreakable when reason dictates the expediency of breaking it. The years of transition saw a great interest being taken in this subject, and much war being waged about it. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: English.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A critical analysis of the writings of Aphra Behn.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: About Mrs Aphra Behn there is practically nothing that can be said with certainty except that she is the author of a number of plays, a few stories and a volume of verse. She has come down to us a dim figure, shrouded from our eyes by the starched and officious bands of nineteenth century morality, so that her life is a legend and her very name a matter of speculation. Some say that while she was a girl she travelled from her English home to America, (l) and others indignantly deny that she did anything of the kind. (2) Some have dubbed her father a barber and others have made him a Lieutenant General. About Mrs Aphra Behn there is practically nothing that can be said with certainty except that she is theauthor of a number of plays, a few stories and a volume of verse. She has come down to us a dim figure, shrouded from our eyes by the starched and officious bands of nineteenthcentury morality, so that her life is a legend and her very name a matter of speculation. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Behn, Aphra, 1640-1689 -- Criticism and interpretation.
English.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Experimental epilepsy. A study of the effects of cerebralwounds and cerebral excisions, with a review of the literature of post traumatic epilepsy.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: That convulsive seizures may follow injuries to the head was probably known by pre-historic man. Nevertheless, despite the age-old recognition of the relationship between headtrauma and certain forms of epilepsy, and despite the untold investigations into the treatment of this unfortunate sequela, amazingly little progress has been made in an understanding of the underlying cause and the basic principles of therapy. Adapting the definition of Lennox and Cobb (1928) as applied to the entire field of convulsive seizures, we may limit ourselves to a discussion of "a syndrome characterized by the sudden appearance of paroxysms, of which convulsive movements or loss of consciousness or both, are a principal element", but which, in the class of convulsions under discussion are associated with definite and demonstrable injury of the brain and its envelopes, due to violence. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Neurosurgery.
